reviews.review_msg: Perhaps as a person, Marnie is interesting to talk to. As a prof, she was disorganised, late for office hours, had very contrasting opinions to her own T.A, and very unclear grading systems. There were many 'low-stakes' assignments that you really had to work for and the final poster was a nightmare. Office hours are crucial for feedback, go often.

This was a really bad course. So many assignments worth so little, and then almost no time to complete projects worth 20% of your grade. When you try to do things different then how she want, you get marks off. Very nice person outside class, but should not be teaching. So much work for such bad result.

I absolutely love Marnie as a person, she was great to talk to outside of class. However, class structure was very disorganized. Lots of "low stakes" assignments, but required a ton of work to get a good mark on. It's not so much about doing well, it's about doing everything exactly wants it. Go for lots of feedback and it's easy to do well.

This class was disorganized from the get-go. You don't actually learn anything in this class except for how to adhere to Marnie's opinions on what scientific writing should look like. Class time was often wasted on useless activities, leaving group project work for your own time. You also only get feedback if you go to office hours.

Marnie was disorganized all semester long, sending her daily schedule out the night before or even a couple hours before class. The way she runs the class lead to minimal amounts of learning and guest speakers from the SLC taught 1/3 of the course. Feedback was useless and peer review system was the opposite of productive.
